text:
Every minute that your brain
has an artery blocked,
millions of brain cells are dying.

Every successful business
starts with a great idea.

Today, moving from concept to reality
is easier than ever before.
Join us as we travel around the world

and meet developers, architects,
and innovators

to learn how they're building
on the AWS Cloud.

Welcome to
'This is My Architecture.'

Welcome to another special episode 
of 'This is My Architecture.'

Today I'm filming from
a slightly less exotic location than usual:
my home, where I've been adapting

to this changing environment
that we find ourselves in.

Today we're going to explore
how technology is changing
the outcomes of urgent stroke care.

One company that's embracing this idea
is Viz.ai,

with the AI standing
for artificial intelligence.

About 1 in 4 of us are expected
to suffer from stroke during our lifetime.

This new technology promises
to dramatically increase survival and recovery.
The process is impressive,

but I'm really interested in understanding
the architecture behind the technology.
Earlier this year, before the pandemic,

I had the opportunity to travel
to Tel Aviv

and spend some time with Viz.ai,
diving deeper into it.
David, what was the big idea for Viz.ai?

So, about 4 years ago, I was hospitalized
at Stanford Hospital
with a suspected stroke.

Before that, I was
a very happy postdoc at Stanford.

But that experience really gave me
the insight into the problems
of stroke workflow.

I was lucky enough to meet Dr. Chris Mansi,
co-founder of Viz and CEO,
who is a neurosurgeon by background,

who told me that he actually lost
numerous patients on the table
due to such workflow delays.

And he shared his vision of connecting
doctors and patients automatically
to avoid and eliminate these delays.

So, you're a technologist.
How did you think that could help?
So, 2016 was a very exciting year.

On the AI side, deep learning technology
was picking up

and really breaking record after record
in computer vision.

Cloud technology was maturing,
providing abilities

to crunch the huge data that comes
out of CT scans automatically in the cloud

and delivering it all the way
to the mobile device of the physician.

Fantastic. Thanks, David.
I can't wait to learn more.
Thank you.

Detecting what kind of stroke
a patient may be having in a timely manner
is crucial for treatment and well-being.

With Viz.ai's new technology,
doctors and medical teams
are able to identify strokes much quicker.

To find out more, let's meet
two world-renowned specialists

in the field of stroke care:
Dr. Adam de Havenon and Dr. Ramesh Grandhi.
Thanks for joining me today.

Thanks for having me.
Yeah, my pleasure, Adrian.

Describe for me what happens
when a patient comes into the hospital.
Once in the stroke center,

what is important is to get them
for their imaging.
They undergo a CAT scan of the head,

because when a person comes in
with a stroke,

we still don't generally know
what type of stroke it is.
But scanners only give you pictures.
Somebody has to look at those pictures
and identify that the artery is blocked.

And how long does it take
to actually analyze those scans?

Once the images are pulled up,
they can be reviewed in a matter of minutes.

However, that's not always the case
at other hospitals.

And the truth of it, Adrian, is that
there just aren't enough neurologists
to be at all these hospitals.
All of them would essentially wait

for a scan to be transferred
to a radiologist.
Going back and forth can slow things down
10, 20, even 30 or 40 minutes.

And when you get that sort of slowdown,
what is the effect on the patient?
It can be quite dramatic.

If we're talking about 30 minutes,
that might be the difference
between leading a very normal life
to your requiring help with basic things

like getting dressed,
going to the bathroom.

So if we look at Viz.ai, how is it changing
your approach to patient care?

When a patient gets a CT scan
at the hospital,

it's immediately transferred to this app
on my phone.
And being able to visualize imaging,
just pulling it up on your phone,
without having to log on to a computer

or wait for the imaging packet to arrive
on your computer screen,
is invaluable.

CT, or Computed Tomography, scans are
high-resolution image slices of the brain.

And they could be huge:
anything from 100 images to 1000.

But how do you get all this data
up to the cloud?

Well, I spoke to Michael at Viz.ai
about how they did it.

So Michael, let's start
with how you collect all those images
from the hospitals.

We deal with different legacy systems,
many makes and models of CT scanners.
They all use DICOM protocol.

We have a virtual machine
inside the hospital

that utilizes AWS CLI and uploads data
directly into an S3 bucket.

In addition to that,
we have another flavor

that uses a VPN connection
between the hospital and the cloud.

But also, we send images back
to the CT scanner after processing

and that happens with the help
of an SQS queue and an S3 bucket.

So once those images are in this S3 bucket,
how does the workflow kick off?

The S3 bucket uses
AWS S3 event notification
and triggers the Lambda.

That Lambda is basically the entry point
into our processing account
and processing pipeline.
We start with the study assembler,

which is the first worker
that processes the data,

and basically builds
from those different DICOM images
a series, a study, and a patient.

And then after that, we have
the study processor,

which it uses as kind of a router
that identifies

the type of algorithm
that needs to run on that specific patient.
They communicate by using a message broker.
We use Apache Kafka.
Next one in line is the ML inference,

which is the heart of the system,
the part that runs the algorithm,

and they all connect
with the state flow RDS.

So, results from one worker are availble
for the other worker through the RDS.
At the heart of Viz.ai is machine learning.

This helps the app discover
vessel occlusions from the CT images.

But to better understand
what the AI is looking for,

we first need to understand
the different types of strokes.

The vast majority of strokes are
what we call ischemic strokes,

where a blood vessel to the brain
is blocked,
typically by a clot,
and that deprives the brain of the blood.

It causes the brain eventually
to die off.

Then we have something called
hemorrhagic strokes,

which are also known as
intracranial hemorrhages.

Intracranial hemorrhages are
a bloody stroke,

and that's when bleeding occurs
in the brain.

Finally, the last type of stroke is called
the subarachnoid hemorrhage,

in which there's bleeding on the surface
of the brain tissue itself,

and that type of stroke represents
about 3% of all strokes.

So, I noticed you used
different auto scaling groups

for these different phases
of the processing.
Why is that?

So, we want to make sure we use
the right EC2 instance
for the right workload.

For example, the ML inference needs
a heavy, fast, intensive GPU power,
and for that we use P3 instances.

While the other processors,
they need lighter processing power,

and for that we can
get away with T instances.

So, great, you're really right-sizing
the cost of your EC2 farms

across these different parts
of your process.

Now, I notice you have
a number of AWS security services.
How have you been using those?

So, since we hold very sensitive data
in the cloud,
we need to be HIPAA compliant,

and also compliant
with other security frameworks.

And for that we use
different AWS security services:
Inspector, Macie, KMS, GuardDuty, etc.

Right, and so Macie, for example,
helps you identify

some personal identifiable information,
or PII information there.

Now, I noticed you have another S3 bucket
over here with results.
What happens from here?

The bucket contains the processing results
of the algorithm.
And by using AWS Cloudfront,

we can show those images
inside a mobile app

in addition to the original images
that arrive from the CT scanner.

And by using Cloudfront, we make sure
that these images are available globally
in a fast manner.

I really see some fantastic integration
that you've done with these AWS services.
Thanks for sharing.
Thank you very much.

So before Viz, a patient who would walk
into a hospital, say in Montana,

would get a scan there and it would go
through a series of handoffs and escalations,

and the person who is actually making
the decision sits in Salt Lake, Utah.
And you can imagine how this takes hours,

and remember with stroke,
every minute counts.

With Viz, the scan goes to the cloud,
and within 3 to 5 minutes is processed,

and the physician in Salt Lake City
gets the alert their phone,

it wakes them up,
they can see the images,

and they step into the workflow
much, much sooner,
and the patients get treated much sooner.

Viz.ai's machine learning technology
further speeds up this process

by alerting a physician
once it detects a potential occlusion.

Let's check in with our doctors one more time
to see how they use this AI technology.

So how does the artificial intelligence
come into play for you as a doctor?
It alerts us even sooner

particularly when patients are
at hospitals

where a radiologist, or a neurologist,
is not looking at the scans immediately.

And that enables us to activate
the cath lab team,
the angio team at these outside hospitals,

and it cuts down on time
that can otherwise be spent
getting them on the table and ready to go

for us to deliver
this life-saving treatment

For example, I was at home,
eating dinner I think,
and my phone alerts,

telling me that there's a patient
with a large vessel occlusion.

Immediately I looked at my phone,
I scrolled through the image,

I saw that, gosh, this is an artery,
we could get this clot out.
And we moved.

We were able to mobilize our efforts
and get that young lady on the table

at her community hospital
while we were driving up,

and the greatest impact was seeing her
walking out of the hospital
two days later.

That ability to both alert me
when there's a problem
and then let me look at the problem,

is quite a game-changer
I would say, Adrian.
Everything that Dr. Grandhi just told us

requires some serious AI ML muscle
to interpret all that data.

Let's head back to Tel Aviv one more time
and speak to Shlomi,

and find out how Viz.ai uses
artifical intelligence
to enable that telecare workflow.

Shlomi, we learned how you deploy
your models into production,

but a big part of your platform
is how you improve them over time.
What were some of the challenges that you faced?

So the first thing we need to know is that,
when dealing with health care,
we need to have a very large sample size

in order to make sure
that every improvement we do to the algorithm

is affecting everybody,
and not just the common cases.

The second thing is that we're
a small company
and we want to run fast.
Right, well, walk us through how you built it.
So the first thing that we're doing,
we're taking the data from our production system

and processing it in a process
we call DI, de-identification.

So we basically take the data
and we strip all the PHI from it,
that's protected health information.

So after this point,
we have data without PHI.

The second process that we are doing
is collecting some metadata from the data
and saving all the results back to S3.
It's a great use of serverless here.

I see Batch.
What are you using that for?

We use Batch in order to overcome
some Lambda limitation,

especially regarding the amount of space
that we have for each Lambda.

Right, so you can run
a lot more of those in parallel.

So, I see your algorithm team here.
What's the experience like for them?
We wanted to have a very simple process

that everybody can use,
so we have a centralized location.

This is Jenkins,
who is orchestrating the entire process.
So the developer will go here to Jenkins,
and here we need to have two inputs.
The first is a branch in GitHub,

and the second of all
is a list of patients.

So once Jenkins starts to work,
it will pull the data from GitHub,

and then it will create a new image
in ECR.

Once that is done, we can start sending
tasks over to Fargate.
So now we are running multiple instances,
one for each patient,

and once this process is over,
we are saving all the data
in a centralized location back in S3.

So your developers are
only ever dealing with code,

never have to worry
about any of the infrastructure,

and you can maintain versions,
which is great.

Now, AWS has
lots of different container services.
Now, why did you choose Fargate?

We chose Fargate because we wanted
a process that would allow us

to scale very fast, but still maintain
a low cost,
instead of using machines and EC2s.

So I see you're using CloudWatch.
How are you using that?
So, each instance will write all the logs to CloudWatch,

and then we are using a Lambda
to transfer all logs to Sumo Logic.

Right, so you can get a full visualization
of what all of this is doing.

Yes.
Great. A lot of automation

has gone into this.
What sort of benefits have you seen?

So, the two main benefits
that we saw from this process,

first of all is the price,
we cut down the price in 60%,
and the second is the development time.

We went from a process that ran 2 weeks
to just 2 hours.

That's amazing.
Thanks for sharing your architecture with us.
Thank you very much.

Viz.ai is in over 300 hospitals
in the United States,
with many more to come around the world.

Medical experts are embracing
these new tools

to interface with one another, to make
the medical workflow much more efficient.

That means vastly better outcomes
for stroke patients
in the years to come.
And that's good news for all of us.

Well, that's a wrap
for this special episode.

Until next time,
stay safe and stay connected.
